title: Is Haruki Murakami the best choice to start reading Japanese literature? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, you can start anywhere depending on your taste. I’m not a big fan of Murakami. I am pretty passionate about Japanese literature, especially the work of Ryonusuke Akutagawa, Yosano Akiko and Yasunari Kawabata, though. I’ll make a list of worthwhile books for you: Kawabata- Snow Country, Thousand Cranes, The Sound of the Mountain, The Master of Go.Tanizaki- The Makioka Sisters, Some Prefer NettlesMishima- Confessions of a Mask, The Sound of the Waves, The Sea of Fertility tetralogySoseki, I am a Cat trilogyYosano Akiko, Midaregami ( tanka)Kobo Abe- The Woman in the DunesKensaburo Ōe- He won the Nobel Prize, but I couldn’t get past the first pages of any of his booksYoshikawa, it’s pulp, but I enjoyed it anyway, MusashiKazuo Ishiguro- I suppose we can include him, as well. Remains of the Day.Natsuo Kirino - Out ( one of my favorite thrillers)Sei Shonagon, The Pillow Book ( Heian period)Lady Murasaki, The Tale of Genji ( Heian period)Akutagawa, short stories, In a Grove, The Nose and many more.Lafcadio Hearn, KaidanDonald Keene, took Japanese citizenship, wrote some wonderful travelogues, essays, bios on JapanHitomaru, one of my favorite poets ( Asuka period)Basho, Edo period, haikuFujiwara no Teika, poet, late Heian periodEnjoy!

If you mean is he a good place to start reading Japanese fiction in Japanese, I’d say yes. Murakami writes clearly and simply. If, however, you want an introduction to Japanese literature, per se, I’d recommend something along the line of Ms. Temmer’s list. In my opinion, Murakami’s work probably should not be considered “literature”, as such, but (sometimes) entertaining, usually well-written popular fiction..
